maml:description.maml:para: Converts a domain FQDN to its NetBIOS name.

Retrieves the NetBIOS name for a specified domain FQDN by checking the cache or querying the directory service. For LDAP providers, it retrieves domain information from the directory. For non-LDAP providers, it extracts the first part of the FQDN before the first period.
Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) to convert to NetBIOS name
ADSI provider to use (LDAP or WinNT)
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
ADSI provider to use (LDAP or WinNT)
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) to convert to NetBIOS name

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
System.String. The NetBIOS name of the domain.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: ConvertTo-DomainNetBIOS -DomainFQDN 'contoso.com' -Cache $Cache

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the fully qualified domain name 'contoso.com' to its NetBIOS name by automatically determining the appropriate method based on available information. The function will check the cache first to avoid unnecessary directory queries.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: ConvertTo-DomainNetBIOS -DomainFQDN 'contoso.com' -AdsiProvider 'LDAP' -Cache $Cache

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the fully qualified domain name 'contoso.com' to its NetBIOS name using the LDAP provider specifically, which provides more accurate results in an Active Directory environment by querying the domain controller directly.

maml:description.maml:para: Use Active Directory Service Interfaces to retrieve an object from a directory
Retrieve a directory entry using either the WinNT or LDAP provider for ADSI
Path to the directory object to retrieve Defaults to the root of the current domain
Credentials to use to bind to the directory Defaults to the credentials of the current user
Properties of the target object to retrieve
Mapping of SID types to descriptions used for converting security identifiers
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Credentials to use to bind to the directory Defaults to the credentials of the current user
Path to the directory object to retrieve Defaults to the root of the current domain
Properties of the target object to retrieve
Mapping of SID types to descriptions used for converting security identifiers

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
[PSCustomObject] for security principals with no directory entry

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: As the current user on a domain-joined computer, bind to the current domain and retrieve the DirectoryEntry for the root of the domain

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-DirectoryEntry distinguishedName : Path : WinNT://ComputerName

dev:remarks.maml:para: As the current user on a workgroup computer, bind to the local system and retrieve the DirectoryEntry for the root of the directory

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a hashtable of well-known SIDs indexed by their NT Account names (captions).

This function takes a hashtable of well-known SIDs (indexed by SID) and transforms it into a new hashtable where the keys are the NT Account names (captions) of the SIDs. This makes it easier to look up SID information when you have the account name representation rather than the SID itself.
Hashtable of well-known Security Identifiers (SIDs) with their properties
Hashtable of well-known Security Identifiers (SIDs) with their properties

dev:type.maml:name: A hashtable containing SID strings as keys and information objects as values.
Returns a hashtable with NT Account names as keys and SID information objects as values.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $sidBySid = Get-KnownSidHashTable $sidByCaption = Get-KnownCaptionHashTable -WellKnownSidBySid $sidBySid $systemInfo = $sidByCaption['NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM']

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a hashtable of well-known SIDs indexed by their NT Account names and retrieves information about the SYSTEM account. This is useful when you need to look up SID information by NT Account name rather than by SID string.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves information about well-known security identifiers (SIDs).

Gets information about well-known security identifiers (SIDs) based on patterns and common formats. Uses Microsoft documentation references for SID information: - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/openspecs/windows_protocols/ms-dtyp/81d92bba-d22b-4a8c-908a-554ab29148ab
Security Identifier (SID) string to retrieve information for
Security Identifier (SID) string to retrieve information for

dev:type.maml:name: A SID string that identifies a well-known security principal.
PSCustomObject with properties such as Description, DisplayName, Name, NTAccount, SamAccountName, SchemaClassName, and SID.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-KnownSid -SID 'S-1-5-32-544'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns information about the built-in Administrators group.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-KnownSid -SID 'S-1-5-18'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns information about the Local System account.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a hashtable of well-known SIDs indexed by their friendly names.

This function takes a hashtable of well-known SIDs (indexed by SID) and transforms it into a new hashtable where the keys are the friendly names of the SIDs. This makes it easier to look up SID information when you know the name but not the SID itself.
Hashtable containing well-known SIDs as keys with their properties as values
Hashtable containing well-known SIDs as keys with their properties as values

dev:type.maml:name: A hashtable containing SID strings as keys and information objects as values.
Returns a hashtable with friendly names as keys and SID information objects as values.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $sidBySid = Get-KnownSidHashTable $sidByName = Get-KnownSidByName -WellKnownSIDBySID $sidBySid $administratorsInfo = $sidByName['Administrators']

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a hashtable of well-known SIDs indexed by their friendly names and retrieves information about the Administrators group. This is useful when you need to look up SID information by name rather than by SID string.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns a hashtable of known security identifiers (SIDs) with detailed information.

Returns a hashtable of known SIDs which can be used to avoid errors and delays due to unnecessary directory queries. Some SIDs cannot be translated using the [SecurityIdentifier]::Translate or [NTAccount]::Translate methods. Some SIDs cannot be retrieved using CIM or ADSI. Hardcoding them here allows avoiding queries that we know will fail. Hardcoding them also improves performance by avoiding unnecessary directory queries with predictable results.

dev:type.maml:name: None. This function does not accept pipeline input.
System.Collections.Hashtable. Contains SIDs as keys and PSCustomObjects with SID information as values.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $knownSids = Get-KnownSidHashTable

dev:remarks.maml:para: This hashtable can be used to look up information about well-known SIDs: $knownSids['S-1-5-18'].DisplayName # Returns 'LocalSystem' $knownSids['S-1-5-32-544'].Description # Returns description of the Administrators group

maml:description.maml:para: Use Active Directory Service Interfaces to search an LDAP directory

Find directory entries using the LDAP provider for ADSI (the WinNT provider does not support searching) Provides a wrapper around the [System.DirectoryServices.DirectorySearcher] class Supports filtering, paging, and customizing which properties to return.
Path to the directory object to retrieve Defaults to the root of the current domain
Number of results to return in each page
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Path to the directory object to retrieve Defaults to the root of the current domain
Number of results to return in each page

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
System.DirectoryServices.SearchResult collection representing the matching directory objects.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Search-Directory -DirectoryPath "LDAP://DC=contoso,DC=com" -Filter "(objectClass=user)" -PageSize 1000 -Cache $Cache

dev:remarks.maml:para: Searches the contoso.com domain for all user objects, retrieving results in pages of 1000 objects at a time. This is useful for efficiently retrieving large sets of directory objects without overwhelming memory resources.
